15.text:
Students, faculty, staff, alumni,
thank you for being here today.

19.text: We have come to talk about our future.

23.text:
But I want to begin the conversation
by reaching back into our past.

28.text:
I begin with a story of a
young professor of philosophy

33.text:
at Princeton University in
the wake of World War II.

37.text:
The professor, at the behest of Dartmouth's
then dean of the faculty, was convinced to pick

44.text:
up from Princeton and move to
Hanover to become the chairman

47.text: of the mathematics department at Dartmouth.

50.text:
His task was to revitalize the department,
filling it with faculty of the first rank,

57.text:
capable of attracting the
brightest students in the nation.

59.text:
It was a risky proposition,
made riskier by the fact

65.text:
that this professor would
be a non-tenured chairman.

67.text:
And yet the philosopher turned mathematician --
who had studied under Einstein -- took the leap.

79.text:
He recruited tenaciously and he built a
stellar department from the ground up.

85.text:
And as a Dartmouth undergraduate,
I had the great fortune

88.text: to be a beneficiary of his efforts.

91.text: But he did not stop there.

94.text:
A computer genius -- he foresaw
that while the invention

97.text: of the computer was an incredible breakthrough,

101.text:
the real revolution would be
putting the computer into homes

108.text: So he helped to invent the language

109.text:
that would make computers
accessible, which we know as BASIC.

113.text: But he did not stop there.

117.text:
He became president of the College,
and he presided with calm during a time

121.text: of tremendous unrest in our country.

125.text:
He inspired and managed the transition of
Dartmouth to a coeducational college --

130.text:
without doubt, the most significant
change in our college's history.

136.text:
I share the story of John Kemeny -- a story
of risk, a story of best-in-class teaching,

143.text:
a story of leadership, a story of visionary
problem-solving, a story of the courage

149.text:
to change -- because it encapsulates perfectly
the incredible promise that is Dartmouth.

156.text:
You have heard me speak before
about my vision for our future.

163.text:
You have heard me speak of Dartmouth becoming
an even stronger magnet for talent --

168.text:
a college that students select above others
because of the educational experiences we offer,

175.text:
and the chance to work directly with outstanding
faculty, a college that faculty choose

181.text:
because of our path-breaking
scholarship and the chance to work

185.text: with the world's most driven students.

188.text:
You have heard me speak of the power
of a liberal arts education in an age

194.text:
when information is ubiquitous
but wisdom is rare.

199.text:
And you have heard me speak of a campus
that is even more intellectually energized,

204.text:
a site of significant academic innovation
and entrepreneurship, a place of big ideas,

219.text:
But our aspirations will never be realized
if we fail to address a vital component:

225.text:
the environment in which
our students live and learn.

229.text:
Like Kemeny, we must recognize a moment in time
when change is necessary to reach our potential.

236.text: And now is such a moment.

240.text:
What is the environment that will enable
Dartmouth to fulfill our potential?

244.text:
As I see it, it is an environment where students
are free of extreme behaviors and part of a safe

252.text:
and healthy campus, where we foster
inclusivity through a variety of options

258.text:
for community building and social interaction,
where students are around-the-clock learners,

266.text:
and, yes, where students continue the
tradition of independently organizing

273.text:
but with greater accountability
and deeper engagement with faculty.

277.text:
This is the vision for the future
of student life at Dartmouth.

282.text: Today, I present to you a program of changes

285.text:
that will move Dartmouth forward
energetically towards that reality.

290.text:
Before I do, I owe enormous gratitude
to the Presidential Steering Committee

296.text:
that has studied these issues
extensively for the last nine months.

312.text:
I thank the committee for their dedication to
the difficult task that was put before them.

318.text:
And I especially thank Barbara Will for her
tireless leadership and her relentless efforts

324.text:
to hear and include the thinking
of the community.

336.text:
The steps that I will share with
you today are informed by research,

339.text:
inspired by crowd-sourced
ideas, and especially directed

343.text:
by the final report advanced
to me by the committee.

347.text:
And while this morning I will detail
some of our major interventions,

351.text:
there are others that we planned, and
they come on top of an impressive actions

356.text: that we have taken in recent years.

358.text:
So I encourage you to visit the
President's website where you can read

362.text:
in detail the comprehensive list of steps
that we'll take to Move Dartmouth forward.

367.text: But let's hit the high points.

370.text:
First, we will fundamentally transform
the residential life at Dartmouth.

377.text:
We envision a campus that is
more inclusive, where faculty

381.text:
and grad students play more influential
roles in the lives of undergraduates,

384.text:
where students learn and grow outside the
classroom, and where we have more options

391.text: for social life and community interaction.

395.text:
Our new housing plan addresses each of these
important needs, and today I am pleased

400.text:
to report that we are aggressively
moving forward to implement it.

405.text: Beginning next year, with the class of 2019,

407.text:
every student who enters Dartmouth will be
placed into one of six house communities.

412.text:
Each community will have a cluster
of residence halls as a home base.

418.text: And from sophomore year on, students will reside

421.text:
within their residential community
whenever they live within our dorms.

424.text:
But even if a student is living in a first-year
dorm, a Greek house, an affinity house,

430.text:
a live-learn community, or off campus,
they will still remain a member

435.text:
of the residential community, included in all
its activities, and partaking of all the rights

444.text:
As part of this initiative, each residential
community will organize and host social

449.text:
and academic programs, and eventually
each will have dedicated space

456.text:
We are committing in excess of $1
million per year to support programming

461.text:
within the residential communities
and other college venues.

466.text:
Each residential community will have a house
professor and graduate students in residence.

471.text:
And we will begin interviewing interested
faculty within the next few weeks,

476.text:
so that they can spearhead faculty
and student involvement in the design

480.text:
of the residential communities
and their activities.

484.text:
As we pilot new spaces and
academic and social programming

487.text:
within these residential communities,
I am asking students, faculty and staff

492.text: and alumni to be deeply involved.

495.text:
We must design the residential community
system that works best for Dartmouth

500.text: and your enthusiasm and ideas will be crucial.

503.text:
At Dartmouth we are working to create a
more inclusive and diverse environment --

510.text:
on and off campus -- and to enrich our community
and strengthen the academic experience.

516.text:
Our new housing model is one step forward
in this regard, but there are others.

522.text:
In addition, we have committed $1 million
per year to support the recruitment

530.text:
Our provost and new vice provost will
focus specifically on this objective.

536.text:
And at the same time, we
will invest in new strategies

540.text:
to recruit a broad socio-economic
demographic of undergraduate students,

544.text:
and to ensure that financial aid
is available for those who need it.

549.text:
The bottom line is that we will work to
ensure that our community conveys a message

554.text:
of inclusion to every student,
faculty and staff member at Dartmouth.

559.text: I like the signs -- signs we got.

565.text:
Second, we will promote a safer
and healthier campus environment.

570.text:
We envision a campus where students are free
of extreme behaviors, where sexual assault

576.text:
and high-risk drinking are
eradicated from our campus.

580.text:
Over the past few years, we have
taken a number of steps to this end.

584.text:
Last June, we adopted a zero-tolerance
sexual assault disciplinary policy,

589.text:
with mandatory expulsion in the most egregious
cases, and have moved to a new model providing

596.text:
for a professional investigation process
with a trained, independent investigator.

601.text:
We have introduced a customized Bystander
Training program that trains students

606.text: to help prevent assault before it occurs.

609.text:
And I know many of you students have
participated in that training and I thank you.

615.text:
Starting next year we will introduce
a comprehensive, four-year education

619.text:
and awareness program for students as well as
first-responder training for faculty and staff.

626.text:
We will roll out a Dartmouth
specific smart-phone safety app.

630.text:
Let the message be heard: we have and we
will continue to take every proven step

636.text:
to prevent sexual assault and to
respond promptly and fairly to reports.

641.text:
When it comes to a safe environment, and
one that is advantageous to learning,

646.text:
we know that excessive drinking is one
of the most pressing challenges we face.

651.text:
Over the past four years, the DCHIP
Program has brought us measurable

658.text:
But still, the Steering Committee found
that high risk drinking is far too prevalent

664.text:
on our campus and that in the vast majority
of alcohol-induced medical transports,

670.text:
it is hard alcohol -- rather than beer or wine
-- that lands students on a hospital gurney.

677.text:
Dartmouth will take the lead among colleges
in banning hard alcohol on our campus.

683.text:
Undergraduate students will not be
permitted to possess or consume hard alcohol

687.text:
in residential spaces or on other college
property, and hard alcohol will not be served

694.text:
at events sponsored by college-recognized
organizations.

699.text:
Penalties for students found in
possession of hard alcohol will ramp up,

703.text:
as will penalties for those who purchase
and provide hard alcohol to minors.

709.text:
And I am asking the entire campus community
to follow suit and not serve hard alcohol

718.text:
These initiatives will pave the way to a campus
that is safer and free of extreme behaviors.

724.text:
But true and lasting change will not come
from top-down policies like these alone.

731.text:
It will come from individuals and
organizations committing to live

736.text: up to a higher standard of behavior.

738.text:
And so, third, we will clarify
and strengthen expectations

747.text:
Today, I want to return to a question
that I posed in my inauguration speech.

752.text:
I want every member of the community
to ask yourself: will your actions

758.text:
and decisions elevate our
community and advance our mission?

761.text: Or will they set us back?

764.text:
To clarify what we expect of individuals, every
student who enrolls at Dartmouth will be asked

770.text: to sign a code of conduct beginning next fall.

773.text:
It will articulate the high expectations -- as
they relate to civility, dignity, diversity,

780.text:
community, and safety -- that
we have for Dartmouth students.

785.text:
These are the fundamentals for every graduate
who wants to go out into the world and lead.

791.text:
There are some actions and behaviors
that no policy can change or regulate.

798.text:
The vile practices online, such
as bullying and anonymous threats

803.text: and attacks, fall into this category.

806.text:
For these behaviors, a student code
of conduct is particularly germane.

811.text:
Our expectation is that students at Dartmouth
act with the same integrity in the shadow

817.text: of the Internet as they do in the light of day.

819.text:
And a student code of conduct will
make this expectation undeniable.

825.text:
Simultaneously, we are going to
clarify and strengthen accountability

828.text:
for student organizations -- especially
as it relates to hosting social events.

834.text:
So on this topic, I would
like to speak in particular

838.text:
about the complex issue of
Greek life at Dartmouth.

842.text:
Over the past several months,
many have suggested

844.text:
that we eliminate fraternities
and sororities and co-eds.

849.text:
Many others have articulated the positive
outcomes of Greek life and advocated

857.text:
At my request, the Steering Committee
looked at colleges and universities

861.text:
that have minimal Greek life and
those that have intense Greek life.

865.text: And they researched, and in some cases visited,

868.text:
institutions that have already
abolished fraternities and sororities.

873.text:
And their research found that every one of our
peers, regardless of the history and intensity

880.text:
of the Greek scene, struggles mightily with high
levels of harmful behaviors on their campus.

885.text:
I have given much thought to the future of
fraternities and sororities on our campus,

891.text:
taking into account the input I've received
and the work of the Steering Committee.

896.text:
And ultimately, I do not believe that
simply eliminating this one aspect

900.text:
of campus life will be a
comprehensive or even effective solution

904.text: to the more pervasive challenges we face.

907.text:
It would not adequately address the
charge I placed before our community

912.text:
of purging extreme behaviors
wherever they occur on campus.

917.text:
Having said that, I maintain
that Greek organizations,

922.text:
and indeed all student organizations
at Dartmouth, must and will be held

927.text:
to much higher standards and a far greater level
of accountability than they ever have before.

934.text:
To be clear, when I speak of accountability,
what I do not mean is simply being accountable

940.text:
for following rules -- for issuing
wristbands or registering parties

947.text:
I speak of an expectation that student
organizations will exhibit behavior befitting

953.text:
Dartmouth's mission and name; that ultimately
student organizations will contribute

959.text:
to an environment that is respectful and
inclusive and conducive to shaping leaders

965.text:
for the future; that they seek to elevate
and not denigrate the Dartmouth experience.

972.text:
And so I have asked the Dean of the College
to clarify in writing what we will expect

976.text: of all student organizations and to put

978.text:
in place an annual review process
to confirm those expectations.

983.text:
This will include an expectation that no student
organization will encourage hazing or engage

990.text:
in pledge terms of any kind, and
that organizations will take steps

995.text: to be inclusive and diversify their membership.

999.text: Going forward, it will be simple.

1002.text:
Organizations that choose not to fulfill
these higher standards will not be part

1008.text:
Let me say that I am pleased and I am
optimistic about the progress I have seen

1013.text:
by student organizations during
the past year, in their willingness

1017.text:
to increase accountability
and root out extreme behavior.

1021.text:
The proposal advanced by the Greek Leadership
Council this fall introduces a comprehensive set

1027.text:
of reforms which includes
steps like the elimination

1031.text:
of pledge term (which they have
already enacted), requiring every house

1036.text:
to have active advisors of more than one
gender, and requiring each fraternity to commit

1042.text:
at least 15% of their social/programming
budget for financial aid.

1047.text: That is just a sampling of their proposals.

1049.text:
Taken together, this set of actions
introduces more serious reform

1053.text: to the system than we have seen in 50 years.

1057.text: But they have to follow through.

1058.text:
And it is my hope that this is only
the beginning of much more to come.

1062.text:
And so lastly, we will strengthen academic rigor
and enhance learning outside the classroom.

1072.text:
Our vision is for Dartmouth to be a
college where every experience contributes

1077.text:
to building leaders with the
wisdom for a complex world.

1081.text:
To achieve this vision, we will work to
create a more vigorous academic environment.

1088.text:
We will infuse campus life with more
opportunities for learning and growth.

1093.text: On this, the faculty must lead.

1095.text:
And today I am asking their help in a number
of areas -- from curbing grade inflation,

1101.text:
to not cancelling classes around
celebration weekends, limiting lay-ups,

1106.text:
to earlier start times for classes
on Tuesday and Thursday mornings.

1111.text:
Just think students, those of you
here today, instead of listening to me

1115.text: in the future, you could be in class.

1121.text:
At the same time, I am asking faculty and staff
to play a larger and more influential role

1126.text:
in the lives of students to
promote learning and growth 24/7.

1131.text:
To that end, I am announcing today a major
investment to expand experiential learning

1136.text:
at Dartmouth, including the creation of a
center within DCAL that will provide expertise

1141.text:
and financial resources for
faculty and students and staff

1145.text:
to pilot new experiential
learning opportunities.

1149.text:
So, these are the steps that we
will take to Move Dartmouth forward.

1154.text:
We will fundamentally transform
residential life,

1157.text:
and in doing so make Dartmouth
a more inclusive community.

1161.text:
We will work to promote a safer
and healthier campus environment.

1168.text:
We will increase expectations of
individuals and student organizations.

1174.text:
And we will strengthen academic
rigor, while expanding opportunities

1180.text:
And to ensure these actions do in fact
mark a turning point in our history,

1187.text:
I have convened an external
Oversight Committee to be chaired

1191.text:
by Tufts President Emeritus Larry
Bacow to evaluate our progress.

1197.text:
This committee will hold us accountable by
reporting to me and the Board of Trustees

1202.text:
on a regular basis on the question of whether we
are doing what we said today that we would do.

1209.text:
In tandem, we will conduct two regular
climate surveys to benchmark our progress.

1214.text:
Beginning in April 2015, we will conduct
the AAU Sexual Assault Climate Survey

1219.text:
on a regular basis, along with a
new Dartmouth campus climate survey

1225.text: to be launched in the fall of 2015.

1227.text:
And we will be transparent about
our progress on all of these fronts.

1231.text:
We will reevaluate and we will retool these
steps as needed until we reach our end goal.

1239.text:
So in closing, let me take you back to
a wintry evening in April of last year

1247.text:
when we first gathered to speak
of moving Dartmouth forward.

1252.text:
As I said to you that evening,
"much is expected of Dartmouth.

1263.text:
It is time to move our outstanding institution
forward to the promise of our future,

1268.text:
the promise captured by Kemeny
that is our legacy to advance.

1274.text:
When we succeed, we will succeed in building an
institution never better prepared for the future

1282.text:
of higher education, never better equipped
to solve the complex challenges of our world,

1290.text:
never better positioned to
prepare graduates with the wisdom,

1298.text:
I look to you -- our students,
faculty, staff, alumni, and parents --

1303.text: to help us step up to the challenge.

1308.text:
Real change requires tenacity and
courage and boldness and leadership.

1314.text:
But if I have learned anything in the last nine
months, it is that no community is more capable

1321.text:
of rising to meet the challenge we face
today than the one I see before me.

1328.text:
Colleges and universities, indeed
communities across the country,

1332.text: face the issues that we've been discussing.

1335.text: We are not alone in facing them.

1339.text: But we will lead in saying "no more."

1342.text:
We will take the lead in
American higher education

1346.text:
in restoring student life to
a safe and sustainable place.

1351.text:
We will offer a campus experience that
is in every way worthy of our name --

1357.text:
that is in every way conducive
to the promise of our future.
